qas.question: What were credits given to European governments disguised as?
Why weren't swaps registered as debts by Eurostat at the time?
What rules did a German derivatives dealer say could be quite legally circumvented through swaps?
What was again revised in May of 2010?
What was Greece's public debt forecast to hit as high of a percentage of GDP of in 2010?
What were credits taken from European governments disguised as?
Why were swaps registered as debts by Eurostat at the time?
What rules did a German derivatives dealer say could never be quite legally circumvented through swaps?
What was left unchanged in May of 2010?
What was Greece's public debt forecast to hit as low of a percentage of GDP of in 2000?

context: According to Der Spiegel, credits given to European governments were disguised as "<a0_0><b5_0>swaps<b5_0/><a0_0/>" and consequently did not get registered as debt because Eurostat at the time <a1_0><b6_0>ignored statistics involving financial derivatives<b6_0/><a1_0/>. A German derivatives dealer had commented to Der Spiegel that "The <a2_0><b7_0>Maastricht<b7_0/><a2_0/> rules can be circumvented quite legally through swaps," and "In previous years, Italy used a similar trick to mask its true debt with the help of a different US bank." These conditions had enabled Greek as well as many other European governments to spend beyond their means, while meeting the deficit targets of the European Union and the monetary union guidelines. In May 2010, the <a3_0><b8_0>Greek government deficit<b8_0/><a3_0/> was again revised and estimated to be 13.6% which was the second highest in the world relative to GDP with Iceland in first place at 15.7% and Great Britain third with 12.6%. Public debt was forecast, according to some estimates, to hit <a4_0><b9_0>120%<b9_0/><a4_0/> of GDP during 2010.
